Scene: Two guards in the woods get spooked
Comparison: The Battle of Oxcross takes place off-screen in the book.
Difference: The Battle of Oxcross takes place off-screen in the book.

Scene: Robb meets Talisa treating a Lannister man
Comparison:
In this scene, Robb meets Lady Talisa, which starts a budding romance. In the book, this character does not exist. Rather, the girl he falls in love with and eventually marries is Jeyne Westerling, daughter of Lord Gawen Westerling from the Crag, a minor vassal house of the Westerlands. 

After Robb marches west to defeat the Lannisters​ at the Crag, he disappears from the book and his romance with Jeyne is entirely off-screen. Once he returns to Riverrun, he is already married to Jeyne. She is not a battlefield healer, but she does nurse Robb back to health after he takes an arrow to the arm storming the Westerling castle.
Difference: In this episode, Robb meets Lady Talisa, which starts a budding romance. In the book, this character does not exist. Rather, the girl he falls in love with and eventually marries is Jeyne Westerling, daughter of Lord Gawen Westerling from the Crag, a minor vassal house of the Westerlands. After Robb marches west to defeat the Lannisters​ at the Crag, he disappears from the book and his romance with Jeyne is entirely off-screen. Once he returns to Riverrun, he is already married to Jeyne. She is not a battlefield healer, but she does nurse Robb back to health after he takes an arrow to the arm storming the Westerling castle.

Scene: Joffrey humiliates Sansa for her brother's win
Comparison:
In the books, before Sansa was beaten, Dontos tries to help her by smashing a melon on her head so Joffrey would end her punishment there. Dontos wasn't there in the series.

It is Boros Blount, rather than Meryn Trant, who beats and strips Sansa in the Throne Room at Joffrey's behest. The Hound yells "enough!" during the spectacle. Tyrion, who is also accompanied by Timett, scolds and threatens Blount in the same way he does to Trant in the TV series. In the books, she is stripped naked, while in the series, Sansa's beating is toned down as the character was below the required age set by UK decency laws.

In the series, Joffrey never brought up the "being feared is better than being loved" statement.
Difference:
It is Boros Blount, rather than Meryn Trant, who beats and strips Sansa in the Throne Room at Joffrey's behest. The Hound yells "enough!" during the spectacle. Tyrion, who is also accompanied by Timett, scolds and threatens Blount in the same way he does to Trant in the TV series. Additionally, Sansa's beating is toned down in the TV series. In the novel, she is stripped naked, which was removed from the series as the character was below the required age set by UK decency laws.
In the books, before Sansa was beaten, Dontos tries to help her by smashing a melon on her head so Joffrey would end her punishment there. Dontos wasn't even there in the series.
Furthermore, in the series he hadn't even interacted Sansa since the time she saved him from being executed in the first episode.
The conversation between Joffrey and Tyrion about Sansa lasted much longer in the books.
Joffrey never brought up the "being feared is better than being loved" statement in the series.

Scene: Joffrey orders a prostitute to hit the other
Comparison: In the books, it is Varys who suggests the whores for Joffrey, not Bronn. The scene where Joffrey brutalizes Ros and the other whore never unfolds. It is unclear if this suggestion is ever acted on.
Difference: It is actually Varys who suggests the whores for Joffrey in the book, not Bronn. In addition, the scene where Joffrey brutalizes Ros and the other whore never unfolds. It is unclear if this suggestion is ever acted on.

Scene: Petyr tries to sniff out Margaery's marriage
Daenerys receives news from the eastern rider
Comparison:
In the books, Jhogo brings Xaro Xhoan Daxos, Pyat Pree and Quaithe to meet Daenerys in Vaes Tolorro, see the dragons and invite her to Qarth.

In the books, Daenerys takes up residence in an abandoned walled city (Vaes Tolorro) for a time. There they eat fruit and drink water and regain much of their strength. They are not desperate to leave this city for Qarth, though Daenerys's followers do believe the abandoned city to be haunted.
Difference:
Kovarro does not appear in the books. Jhogo is the third Bloodrider, but his name was changed to Rakharo.
In the novel, Daenerys takes up residence in an abandoned walled city (Vaes Tolorro) for a time. There they eat fruit and drink water and regain much of their strength. They are not desperate to leave this city for Qarth, though Daenerys's followers do believe the abandoned city to be haunted.

Comparison: In the books, Arya's death list includes more people. The full list is: the Mountain, Dunsen, Polliver, Chiswyck, Rafford, the Tickler, the Hound, Amory Lorch, Ilyn Payne, Meryn Trant, Joffrey, Cersei and Weese.
Difference: In the books, Arya's death list includes more people. The full list is: the Mountain, Dunsen, Polliver, Chiswyck, Rafford, the Tickler, the Hound, Amory Lorch, Ilyn Payne, Meryn Trant, Joffrey, Cersei and Weese.

Scene: Petyr offers Catelyn a trade from Tyrion
Comparison:
The Lannisters never sent Littlefinger or anyone else to Renly's camp in the books. He is sent to treat the Tyrells, but in Highgarden, and only long after Catelyn departed.

Catelyn does not receive Ned's bones at Renly's camp; she gets them when she returns to Riverrun later in the book.

In the books, Cleos Frey (Alton Lannister's book counterpart), not Littlefinger, is the one who brings Catelyn the Lannisters' offer to exchange Jaime for her daughters. The conversation takes place at Riverrun, not at Renly's camp. Cleos tells Catelyn that Sansa is held at the Red Keep, and admits he has no idea what has become of Arya; he does not attempt to persuade Catelyn to act behind Robb's back.
Difference:
The Lannisters never sent Littlefinger or anyone else to Renly's camp in the books. He is sent to treat the Tyrells, but in Highgarden, and only long after Catelyn departed.
Catelyn and Littlefinger never saw each other again after their meeting at King's Landing, where he lied to her about the dagger.
Catelyn does not receive Eddard's bones at Renly's camp; she gets them when she returns to Riverrun later in the novel. She does not order the bones to be taken to Winterfell in the series either.
In the books, Cleos Frey (Alton Lannister's book counterpart), not Littlefinger, is the one who brings Catelyn the Lannisters' offer to exchange Jaime for her daughters. The conversation takes place at Riverrun, not at Renly's camp. Cleos tells Catelyn that Sansa is held at the Red Keep, and admits he has no idea what has become of Arya; he does not attempt to persuade Catelyn to act behind Robb's back.

Scene: The Mountain selects someone for torture
Comparison:
In the books, the sentence "a naked man has few secrets, but a flayed man's got none" is not said by Roose Bolton, but is said by a man named "Reek" (Ramsay in disguise) to Theon Greyjoy.

There is no mention in the books that Eddard Stark outlawed flaying in the North.
Difference:
In the books, the sentence "a naked man has few secrets, but a flayed man's got none" is not said by Roose Bolton, but is said by a man named "Reek" (actually, Ramsay in disguise) to Theon Greyjoy.
There is no mentioning in the books that Eddard Stark outlawed flaying in the North.

Scene: The Baratheon brothers meet in parley
Comparison:
In the books, the reason Renly and Stannis meet is because Stannis has besieged Storm's End, the seat of Renly. It is not made clear why Stannis and Renly parley. Catelyn and Stannis are the first to gather. Renly joins the meeting shortly later, perhaps deliberately, as some kind of game - the first to arrive must wait on the other.

In the books, the parley is much longer. Stannis tells Catelyn and Renly about the investigation he and Jon Arryn conducted, and about the incestuous relationship between Jaime and Cersei. Based on that information, Catelyn deduces the truth about Bran's fall.
Difference:
In the books, the reason Renly and Stannis meet is because Stannis has besieged Storm's End, the seat of Renly. It is not made clear why Stannis and Renly parley.
Catelyn and Stannis are the first to gather. Renly joins the meeting shortly later, perhaps deliberately, as some kind of game - the first to arrive must wait on the other.
In the book, the parley is much longer. Stannis tells Catelyn and Renly about the investigation he and Jon Arryn conducted, and about the incestuous relationship between Jaime and Cersei. Based on that information, Catelyn deduces the truth about Bran's fall.

Comparison:
In the books, Daenerys is brought to Qarth by Xaro Xhoan Daxos, Pyat Pree and Quaithe. Once there, they are immediately let into the city, without the events at the gates from the series. The city residents warmly welcome Daenerys and her followers, with Drogon clearly visible, and no one asks about the dragons.

Xaro is described as having pale skin and a long, beak-like nose crusted with jewels: rubies, opals and flakes of jade in the books, while in the series he is has black skin. It is also implied in the books that Xaro is homosexual, while in the series he clearly desires Daenerys.

The Thirteen of Qarth fight for dominion over Qarth with the Tourmaline Brotherhood, the Ancient Guild of Spicers and the Pureborn; they are not the only ones charged with governance.

There is no Spice King in the books; however, his alias is a reference to a merchant organization in Qarth, the Ancient Guild of Spicers, that does not appear on the TV Series.
Difference:
Qarth has three walls in the novels, thirty, forty and fifty feet high respectively, each intricately carved with scenes of animals, warfare, and lovemaking.
In the novels, Daenerys is brought to Qarth by Xaro Xhoan Daxos, Pyat Pree and Quaithe. The three meet Daenerys in Vaes Tolorro, being brought to her by Jhogo. They have come to see the dragons and invite her to Qarth. Once there, they are immediately let into the city, without the events at the gates from the series. The city residents warmly welcome Daenerys and her followers, with Drogon clearly visible, and no one asks about the dragons.
Xaro is described as having pale skin and a long, beak-like nose crusted with jewels: rubies, opals and flakes of jade in the books, while in the series he is has black skin. It is also implied in the books that Xaro is homosexual, while in the series he clearly desires Daenerys.
The Thirteen of Qarth fight for dominion over Qarth with the Tourmaline Brotherhood, the Ancient Guild of Spicers and the Pureborn; they are not the only ones charged with governance.
There is no Spice King in the books; however, his alias is a reference to a merchant organization in Qarth, the Ancient Guild of Spicers, that does not appear on the TV Series.

Scene: Tywin turns the prisoners to slaves
Comparison:
Although Arya is at Harrenhal at the same time as Tywin Lannister, she is not appointed his cupbearer and they never converse. Arya serves in various roles while at the castle, working for several people. Going by the name "Weasel", she works for the steward at Harrenhal.

Arya's gender is revealed during the journey to Harrenhal where she had no restroom privacy, not by Tywin.
Difference:
Though Arya is at Harrenhal with Tywin Lannister, she is not appointed his cupbearer and they never converse. Arya serves in various roles while at the castle, working for several people. Going by the name "Weasel", she works for the steward at Harrenhal.
Arya's gender is revealed during the journey to Harrenhal where she had no restroom privacy, not by Tywin.

Comparison: In the books, Tyrion makes Lancel admit not only that he sleeps with Cersei, but also that he had a part in Robert's death.
Difference: In the book, Tyrion makes Lancel admit not only that he sleeps with Cersei, but also that he had part in Robert's death.

Scene: Davos rows Melisandre into the island
Comparison: Davos does row Melisandre to a cavern, although for a different assassination.

Scene: Melisandre gives birth to a demon
Comparison: In the series, Melisandre gives birth to a shadow in front of Davos, outside Renly's camp. In the book there are two shadow assassinations. The birth Davos witnesses is the second one when it is sent to kill Ser Cortnay Pentrose, the castellan of Storm's End. He has to row Melisandre into a cavern under the castle as there are protective spells built into the castle walls.
Difference: In the TV series, the shadow Melisandre in sight of Davos happens outside Renly's camp. In the book there are two shadow assassinations. The birth Davos witnesses is the second one when it is sent to kill Ser Cortnay Pentrose, the castellan of Storm's End (not included in the TV series). He has to row Melisandre into a cavern under the castle as there are protective spells built into the castle walls.
